title: Finding High-Quality Content in Social Media

author: Carlos Castillo, EURECAT, Technology Centre of Catalonia

Now given the the restriction of our system, we have clicks for the questions but the answers don't have an individual page so we don't track the clicks for them.

Such as this basic density, another thing.

In well formed questions and others not so much.

For the users.

You can use propagation algorithms such as page rank or hits on top of each of these graphs and each of them will give you sometimes independent features.

You have an answer and you have the person who has written this answer and the question he has asked before his history of answers an to the other direction.
You have the person who asked the question that I have just answered.
So this means that for every given item you can after after generating the features you can collect more features from the neighborhood.
Finally, our learning setting is very simple.
We use decision trees and we.
Labeled data of about 6000 questions and 8000 answers.
We feed a lot of these.
We feed all these features into the classifier and then we evaluate using precision and recall at the optimal setting for the F measure and the area under the curve.
And there are secret.
Let's look at the result for finding high quality questions for finding high quality questions.
Our baseline is to use word engrams, and with word engrams.
You don't get very far.
The questions are very short and they're hard to classify using only the word N grams.
If you add text analysis, you improved a lot.

If you add the usage data to the engrams then you also get an improvement if you add the community features you also get an improvement and in this particular case, if you want to find a high quality questions using all these features you can find about 77% of the high quality questions automatically with 79% of precision which is way better.
That what you obtained using a standard straightforward text classification.
In the case of finding high quality answers, you also start with a baseline, which in this case is better than.

In this case you don't have clicks because the answers don't have individual pages, but in this case the text analysis gets you pretty far, so only apply the text analysis techniques that I showed at the beginning.

Now if you add the.
Relations the community features doesn't improve the accuracy of this classifier to match.
Now in the paper there is a the framework for the estimation of the quality in social media.
There is this model for the relationship among contributors that can be used not only in Yahoo answer but in any other social media site setting.
There are details like combining.
What happens if you combine 2 features or two sets of features and so on.
Now what did we learn with this paper?
First, the human, the training data that we received even when it was produced by professional editors with very clear guidelines.
Guidelines have in general are relatively low agreement.
So even when you are given an extensive set of guidelines, you still don't agree on what's the high quality items all the time.
Sometimes you disagree.
The other things I think that we think we learn was that the classification of questions and answer is substantially different, and it's actually harder than a standard document classification.
But it can be.
It can be improved if you aggregate other features that are orthogonal to the content of the items themselves.
As future work, we want to explore what happens if, instead of aggregating these features and then running a standard classifier, we try to do relational learning over the data.
There's still something that we want to try.
Well, everything else is in the paper.
If you have any questions I will try to answer them.
Thank you.
